content: SHORT TITLE; DEFINITIONS. The "Online Investor Protection Act of 1999" defines key terms such as the Securities and Exchange Commission, Internet, interactive computer service, and investment adviser. The "Online Investor Protection Act of 1999" defines key terms related to investment regulation, including terms like "investment company," "registered broker or dealer," and "retail investor." The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include a new section 35B for online trading disclosures. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include a new section 35B requiring online brokers to disclose information on system outages, steps taken to address them, and risk management unique to online trading. The Commission may exempt certain brokers from these requirements. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include a new section 35B requiring online brokers to disclose information on system outages, steps taken to address them, and risk management unique to online trading. The Commission may exempt certain brokers from these requirements. Definitions for terms like 'Internet', 'interactive computer service', and 'online broker or dealer' are provided in this section. The new section 35B of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 mandates online brokers to disclose system outage information and risk management specific to online trading. Definitions for terms like 'Internet', 'interactive computer service', 'online broker or dealer', 'online securities transaction', and 'retail investor' are provided in this section. SEC. 3. EXTENDING DISCIPLINARY DISCLOSURES TO THE INTERNET. Section l5A of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require registered securities associations to maintain a system for inquiries about disciplinary actions and proceedings involving their members. Associations can charge reasonable fees for responses to inquiries from entities other than individual investors. Section 15A of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require registered securities associations to maintain a system for inquiries about disciplinary actions involving their members. Associations can charge fees for responses to inquiries from entities other than individual investors. Additionally, a limitation on liability is established for registered securities associations under this subsection. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is also amended to include provisions for filing requirements and costs associated with such filings for investment advisers. The Commission requires an entity to establish and maintain a system for inquiries about disciplinary actions involving investment advisers. The entity must respond promptly to inquiries and recover costs associated with the system. An entity designated under subsection (b)(1) can charge reasonable fees for responses to inquiries and is not liable for actions taken in good faith. Amendments are made to the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the National Securities Markets Improvement Act of 1996 is repealed. SEC. 4. ELECTRONIC ACCESS TO COMMISSION INFORMATION. Brokers, dealers, investment companies, and advisers must provide retail investors with information on investor education and fraud prevention through a link to the Commission website. SEC. 5. CIVIL PENALTIES FOR INTERNET-RELATED VIOLATIONS. The Commission will issue regulations within 6 months to enforce penalties for internet-related violations. The Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to double penalties for violations involving the use of the Internet or interactive computer services. The Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are amended to double penalties for violations involving the use of the Internet or interactive computer services. This applies to cases where the Internet or interactive computer services are used in the act or omission resulting in a violation. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to double penalties for Internet-related violations involving the use of the Internet or interactive computer services. This applies when the Internet or interactive computer services are used in the act or omission resulting in a violation. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to double penalties for Internet-related violations involving the use of the Internet or interactive computer services as part of the act or omission resulting in a violation. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to double penalties for Internet-related violations. SEC. 6. STUDY AND REPORT ON MARKET IMPACT OF ONLINE TRADING. The Commission will study the effects of retail investors trading securities online, including the risks of fraud and market volatility in day trading activities. They will also examine the impact on individual companies and investors, as well as the quality of execution through online trading services. The Commission will study the effects of retail investors trading securities online, including the impact on execution promptness and purchase/sale prices. They will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. Authorization of $70,000,000 for the Office of Internet Enforcement of the Securities and Exchange Commission for fiscal years 2000 through 2004 for Internet enforcement and investor protection activities.
